text:
So our last speaker
for today is Raj Kumar.

He's going to be talking with
us about material science
and engineering.

So I encourage you
to think about how

you might use chemistry in
various sorts of engineering,

and material
science engineering,

and what the interplay between
all of these things might be.

All right, can
everyone hear me OK?
Awesome.

Well, thank you so much
for the introduction.
Yeah, my name is Raj Kumar.

I'm a lecturer and the director
of undergraduate studies

in our Materials Science
and Engineering Department.

It's really nice to
be here in person.

The last couple of times we've
done this for engineering I
students, it's been on Zoom.

So it's a lot nicer, I
think, to be in front of you
all here today.

And following up from some
of the comments earlier,
I have a quick poll.

Before you enrolled
in this class,

raise your hand if
you had ever heard

of what materials science
and engineering is.
Wow, OK.

This is getting better
and better every year.

It looks like maybe half
or a little more than half,
which is great.

For all of you who didn't have
your hand raised, that was me.

When I was my first
quarter of undergrad,

I had no idea what material
science and engineering is.

So like many of you,
I was in your shoes.

And I ended up
finding this major

and getting really
excited about it.

So I'll just take a
few minutes to explain
why it might be for you.

Just a quick overview,
since several of you

hadn't heard of what material
science and engineering is all

about, what we really care
about is understanding

how the structure of
the materials that we

use all the time influence the
properties that we care about.
So what do I mean by structure?
What do I mean by properties?

Well, it turns out that the
way that individual atoms are

arranged or groups of atoms
create a nanostructure,

or what the chemical
structure might be,

or the electronic
structure of a material

might be dramatically influences
how it performs mechanically,

electrically, chemically,
biologically, thermally, et
cetera.

And if we can tune what the
structure of those materials

are and we can characterize
what that structure actually is,

then we can set
what its properties

and ultimate
performance might be.

Conversely, as an
engineer, which I am,
which is really fun.

And we get to do--
we get to say, well,

wouldn't it be great
if my iPhone could

be charged once a week
instead of once a day,

or my electric vehicle could
drive 1,000 miles instead
of 300 miles.

That's what's called a
performance benchmark.

And if we set some
goals, and means,

approach of looking at material
science and engineering,

we can figure out
and back track what

are the properties, what
is the structure, and what

is the way we can
process materials

to get to that benchmark,
to achieve our goals that we
care about.

So this is the
approach that we take,

regardless of if we're
interested in designing better

batteries, we're designing
health care technologies,

we're designing novel electronic
structures and devices.

All sorts of fields of material
science and engineering

touch a lot of the
different applications
that we care about in society.

So when you might
ask the question,

where is material
science engineering,

I could tell you physically
where it is on campus, not too
far from here.

But I think what
matters more is where

it touches all of the
different amazing applications

that Stanford students and
faculty get to work on and get
to really tackle.

So regardless of you're
interested in materials

for energy storage,
materials for computing

and electronics, biomedical
devices, medical diagnostics,

manufacturing, and many, many
other topics and disciplines,
we do research.

And we collaborate and
connect with others

on campus to solve
some of these really

important grand challenges
in science and engineering.

So I want to walk through just
two quick applications with you
today.

I would walk
through so many more

because I think they're
really exciting.

But in the short amount of
time, I'll just have two for you
today.

So on the topic of batteries
that John Hardy brought up

just a moment ago, if you look
at the battery pack that's

in a Tesla, or the battery
that's in your smartphone,

or laptops that you have in
front of you, who can tell me,

what's the ion that's traveling
back and forth in the battery?
Lithium.
Lithium.
Yes, lithium.

All of the batteries we use
are lithium ion batteries.
That's right.

OK, and so if you take
apart that battery pack

that John showed for
the iPhone and you

take a look at the
negative electrode that's

called the anode, it will
look something like this.

OK, it has a copper, typically,
current collector, which
is just this big block film.

And it has this porous
composite that's made of carbon

and polymeric binder that
sticks things together

and a few other additives
in there as well.

And this is what allows lithium
to shuttle back and forth

from anode to cathode
to charge and discharge

that battery that's in your
smartphone, in your laptop,
in your electric vehicle.

So it turns out that
lithium is the third element
on the periodic table.

We saw the periodic
table a few moments ago.

And lithium, that means it's
a really, really small ion.
It's really hard to see.
How do you see lithium?

Well, it turns out there's
these set of techniques known

as X-ray characterization
techniques that

allow us to visualize
the movement of ions
back and forth.

So I have a little
bit of a video here.

This is courtesy of
Professor Will Chueh,
a faculty in our department.

His group does a lot of cutting
edge research on new battery
technologies.

And what they were interested
in this study was seeing,

does the shape of
these carbon particles,

those are the ones
that store the lithium.

Lithium essentially stack in
between the layers of carbon.

Is there a relationship
between the size and the shape

of these particles and
how lithium ends up

going in and out to charge
and discharge the battery?

So what you're seeing here is
that these carbon particles
are fully lithiated.
They are saturated with lithium.

And as this battery,
essentially, is run,

we can see the lithium
leaving in each

of these individual particles
to the point where, at the end,

all the lithium has been
extracted and removed.

OK, anybody notice anything
curious about this picture?
Anyone?
Yeah, in the back.

The different shapes go
green at varying rates.

And then at the very
end, it goes [INAUDIBLE]
Yeah, varying rates.

And then they all
go away at the end.

And what you'll
notice as well, it's

an excellent observation,
which you'll also

notice is that the
lithium doesn't

get removed continuously
across the entire particle.
There are hotspots.
Certain spots go green first.

So what that means
is that there are

preferential sites for
lithium to leave these carbon
particles.

And what this showed Professor
Chueh's team is that if you

tailor the surface structure or
the morphology of these carbon

particles, maybe there's a way
to make it easier for lithium
ions to shuttle back and forth.
What could that lead to?

Well, potentially
batteries that charge
and discharge more efficiently.

And so that when you go
to your charging station,

instead of an hour
to charge, it only

takes 10 minutes or
something like that.

So this was an initial study
that they've really worked

on a lot more in
the last few years

to show that the structure
of the things that

go inside our
battery anodes have

a key impact on their
properties and performance

of those batteries
that we care about.

OK so one more example that I
want to quickly go through is--

I again, my background is in
batteries and energy materials.

But over the last few
years, like many of you,

I've gotten really interested
in biology and really interested
in health care, especially.

And so several of our
faculty and our department

work on materials for health
care, for health diagnostics,

for biomedical implants,
and many other applications.

And so one of these
applications comes

from Professor
Guosong Hong's lab,

where his group is really
interested at trying

to probe the brain and
trying to understand

how do those neural functions
in our brain really work.

And it turns out, that has a
lot of important applications
in neurodegenerative diseases.

So I have a family
member with Alzheimer's.

And so that's a big,
important thing for me
to understand and think about.

And so the idea is, well, what
if we could create probes that
go directly into our brain?

Now it turns out, in order to
do that, we need probes that

essentially match the mechanical
properties of your brain
tissue.
And your brain's soft.

So if you stick an electronic
probe or a needle in that,

that's going to be a
little bit of a problem.

So what if we design conductors
that are as soft as water
and can float?

So this is an example of
injectable copper films

that can actually be
injected into the brain
and monitor electronic activity.

So you can measure
neural activity

and maybe figure out
something along the lines of,

what is going wrong when we
have these neurodegenerative
diseases?

What is the impact in
our neural function?

With the broader idea
that, eventually, you

could create these networks
of injectable copper probes

and really understand, again,
what the overall function is

of the brain to treat disease
and, potentially even,

regain motor function for folks
who suffer from paralysis,

or other loss of spinal,
or neural activity as well.

So these are just two examples
of where materials science
and engineering shows up.
There are many, many more.

And unfortunately, I can't talk
to you all about them today,
but I would love to.

So come stop by
and chat with me.

Really, really
briefly, our department

is a Department, of 22 faculty,
about 40 undergraduates, many,
many more graduate students.

And we have lots of
different classes
offered throughout the year.

And I think what makes this
great is our department

culture really combines
everyone together.

We have lots of
different events where

you see faculty, graduate
students, postdocs,

undergrads all together, and
getting to chat about some

of the things that they're
passionate about and interested
in.

We have a really vibrant
undergraduate community.

So hopefully, I think these
slides will get shared later.

So you don't have to write
any of these links down,

but we have a great
undergraduate student

organization, SUMS, that puts
on study nights, guest speaker,

and different industry tours,
and other great events for you

to learn more about
our department culture,

meet some of our
fellow students,

and get connected to our
broader materials community.

This question I get asked a
lot, where do MatSci majors go?

And the answer really is
everywhere and anywhere,

whether you're
interested in going

into big companies like
Intel, and SpaceX, and Tesla,
and Apple.

Whether you're
interested in working at

start up ventures, and
again, the biomedical space,

the energy space, the
electronic computing space,

going to graduate school,
working at national labs,
education public policy.

We have students go
everywhere and anywhere.

So material science
and engineering degree

can really take you to
a lot of great places.

We have some great
courses offered

for students who are
interested in just checking out

what is material
science and engineering.

So one of them that I'm going
to highlight briefly right now

is MatSci 10, but there's
many others out there.

MatSci 10 is a class that
actually I teach this fall.

And it's a way--
maybe some of you

are already enrolled in
the class, which is great.

But it's a way for
you to learn more

about where are the career
opportunities in material
science and engineering.

And I talked earlier
about how our major
is really interdisciplinary.

And that really shows from
the speakers that we invite.

They talk routinely
about whether they

work in the fields of energy and
sustainability, biomaterials,

regenerative
medicine, atomic scale

engineering, for electronics
and nanotechnology.

They work with so many different
other engineer, scientists,

technologists, economists,
business leaders

as well to make the
cutting edge technologies

that we rely on every day and
that we hope to bring here

in the near future
to help solve, again,

some of these really
important challenges.

Last thing I want to end with
is, a lot of our students

really take a liking to
getting involved in research
while they're here at Stanford.

I think research is a great
way to supplement your learning

and classes by getting to
do things that are hands on

and getting some really
great opportunities to work

with graduate
students and faculty

on some of these
cutting edge problems
that I briefly talked about.

So we have a great
MatSci REU program,
which is over the summer.

You get paid to come do research
at Stanford over the summer

and get to work in a cohort
of about 20 of your peers

on a really wide variety of
different research topics.

And we recently
started, last year,

this undergraduate
research grants
program, this URG program.

So this is a way to
get paid to do research

in the winter and spring quarter
for about 10 hours a week
or so for the two quarters.
Happy to chat about you--

chat with you about
that in the Q&A.
OK, so really quick.

Why did I choose material
science and engineering?

Remember I told you I took an
intro level course on scanning
electron microscopes.

These are the pictures that
I took as an 18-year-old,

that I got to actually see
what a vinyl record looks

like under an
electron microscope.
This is a vinyl record.

So if you are into
'70s audio media

and have a vinyl
collection, this

is what it looks like
at the micron scale.

And this is the shiny
side of a compact disk,
OK, so the back side.

So this shows you how
we read and write data
on compact disks.

So it was being
able to get to see

what these traditional materials
that you see with your eyes

on a daily scale, what
they look like deep down

and how it informs how we make
these structures to impact

the properties and
performance that we

use on these materials
every single day.

And by getting
involved in MatSci,

I was really exposed to
an interdisciplinary way

of thinking, which
I think really

matters in solving some of
these cutting edge problems
that we face today.

So with that, these
are some reasons

why you might choose material
science and engineering.

I'm happy to talk about
that a little bit more.

Thank you so much
for your attention.
I really appreciate it.
